Myth: This bill sets a bad precedent and could have far-reaching effects across the country. 
 
Fact: This legislation is extremely narrow and targeted to solely address the immediate crisis facing the Giant Sequoias, which only cover 37,000 acres.

Myth: This legislation waives environmental reviews under a so-called emergency.

Fact: There are no environmental review waivers in the bill; it simply codifies existing authority the agency already uses in times of emergency. 20% of sequoias have died ‚Äì this is a true emergency

Myth: SOS would "expedite potentially harmful logging projects‚Ä¶ & will do nothing to protect these trees‚Äù

Fact: There's scientific consensus that restorative thinning & prescribed burning are needed to restore the health/resiliency of the groves & protect them from future fires

Myth: @forestservice + @NatlParkService already have several authorities & categorical exclusions for this work.

Fact: Current authorities are insufficient. The new authorities were developed in collab w/ federal, state, tribal & local land managers who requested new authorities

Myth: There is already active management occurring on Giant Sequoia groves. 
 
Fact: Not at the pace and scale needed. It would take the @forestservice approximately 52 years to just treat the 19 highest-priority groves at risk of experiencing devastating wildfires.

Myth: The SOS Act waives the National Environmental Policy Act, Endangered Species Act, and National Historic Preservation Act. 
 
Fact: The SOS Act does not waive any environmental reviews and sets up clear guidelines for how land managers should comply with these laws.

The #SaveOurSequoias Act (SOS) is a comprehensive, bipartisan bill that immediately addresses the imminent threats facing one of the most iconic tree species on the planet. 

Unfortunately, there are a few misconceptions about the bill. Let's dive in ‚¨áÔ∏è
